column1: Cumberland is a city in and the county seat of Allegany County
column3: United States. It is the primary city of the Cumberland
column4: MD-WV Metropolitan Statistical Area. At the 2010 census
column5: the city had a population of 20
column7: and the metropolitan area had a population of 103
column9: Cumberland is a regional business and commercial center for Western Maryland and the Potomac Highlands of West Virginia.

column1: Historically Cumberland was known as the "Queen City"
column2: as it was once the second largest in the state. Because of its strategic location on what became known as the Cumberland Road through the Appalachians
column3: after the American Revolution it served as a historical outfitting and staging point for westward emigrant trail migrations throughout the first half of the 1800s. In this role
column4: it supported the settlement of the Ohio Country and the lands in that latitude of the Louisiana Purchase. It also became an industrial center
column7: and the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal
column9: D.C. and is now a national historical park. Today

column1: Industry declined after World War II. Much of the later urban
column2: business and technological development in the state has been concentrated in eastern coastal cities. Today the Cumberland
column3: MD-WV Metropolitan Statistical Area is one of the poorest in the United States
column4: ranking 305th out of 318 metropolitan areas in per capita income.

column1: Cumberland was named by English colonists after the son of King George II
column3: the Duke of Cumberland. It is built on the site of the mid-18th century Fort Cumberland
column4: the starting point for British General Edward Braddock's ill-fated attack on the French stronghold of Fort Duquesne (present-day Pittsburgh) during the French and Indian War
column5: the North American front of the Seven Years' War between the French and the British. (See Braddock expedition.) This area had long been settled for thousands of years by indigenous peoples. The fort was developed along the Great Indian Warpath which tribes used to travel the backcountry.

column1: Cumberland also served as an outpost of Colonel George Washington during the French and Indian War
column2: and his first military headquarters was built here. Washington returned as President of the United States in 1794 to Cumberland to review troops assembled to thwart the Whiskey Rebellion.

column3: railroad and canal junction. It became the second-largest city in Maryland after the port city of Baltimore. It was nicknamed "The Queen City". Cumberland was the terminus
column4: and namesake
column5: of the Cumberland Road (begun in 1811) that extended westward to the Ohio River at Wheeling
column6: West Virginia. This was the first portion of what would be constructed as the National Road
column10: many black fugitives reached their final stop on the underground railroad beneath the floor of the Emmanuel Episcopal Church. A maze of tunnels beneath and an abolitionist pastor above provided refuge before the final five mile trip to freedom in Pennsylvania.The surrounding hillsides were mined for coal and iron ore
column11: and harvested for timber that helped supply the Industrial Revolution. The Chesapeake and Ohio Canal had its western terminus here; it was built to improve the movement of goods between the Midwest and Washington
column13: the eastern terminus. Construction of railroads superseded use of the canal
column14: as trains were faster and could carry more freight. The city developed as a major manufacturing center

column1: With the restructuring of heavy industry in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic states following World War II
column2: the city lost many jobs. As a result
column3: its population has declined by nearly half
column4: from 39
column5: 483 in the 1940 census to fewer than 20

column1: Cumberland is in the Ridge and Valley physiographic province of the Appalachian Mountains at 39°38′52″N 78°45′46″W (39.647687
column3: at the junction of the North Branch of the Potomac River and Wills Creek. The majority of the land within the city lies in a valley created by the junction of these two streams. Interstate 68 runs through the city in an east/west direction
column4: as does Alternate U.S. 40
column5: the Old National Road. U.S. Highway 220 runs north/south. Parts of Wills Mountain
column7: and Shriver Ridge are also within the city limits.

column1: The abandoned Chesapeake and Ohio Canal is now part of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park. The canal's towpath is maintained

column4: D.C.

column1: Cumberland is at the eastern entrance to the Cumberland Narrows (or "The Narrows")
column2: a water gap along Wills Creek that crosses the central ridge of the Wills Mountain Anticline at a low elevation between Wills Mountain to the north and Haystack Mountain to the south. Cliffs and talus of the two mountains' Tuscarora quartzite caprock are prominent within the Narrows. These geological features provide Cumberland a western backdrop of the two mountains and the narrow gap between them.

column1: The Cumberland Narrows acts as a western gateway from Cumberland to the Appalachian Plateau and the Ohio River Valley beyond. The Old National Road
column3: passes through the Narrows. The former Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's main line between Baltimore/Washington and Pittsburgh
column4: now part of the CSX system
column5: and a former line of the Western Maryland Railroad
column6: now used by the steam- and diesel-powered excursion trains of the Western Maryland Scenic Railroad

column1: A prominent rocky outcropping at the south end of Wills Mountain in the Cumberland Narrows is known as Lover's Leap.
Cumberland lies at the beginning of the transition from a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa) to a humid subtropical climate (Cfa)
column2: although bearing far more characteristics of the former
column3: with a range of temperatures significantly lower than those in the central and eastern part of Maryland
column4: mostly in the form of depressed nighttime lows.

column1: The region has four distinct seasons
column3: humid summers
column4: and moderate winters (compared to surrounding communities
column5: Cumberland receives milder winters and less snow). Monthly daily mean temperatures range from 31.9 °F (−0.1 °C) in January to 76.8 °F (24.9 °C) in July
column6: with temperatures exceeding 90 °F (32 °C) on 34.5 days of the year and dipping to 10 °F (−12 °C) or below on 7 nights per winter. Average seasonal snowfall totals 30.3 inches (77 cm). The record high is 109 °F (43 °C) set in July 1936 and August 1918
column7: both of which are state record highs
column8: while the record low is −14 °F (−26 °C) set at the current site on January 18–19 1994 and January 20–21

A block west of the downtown pedestrian mall is the Western Maryland Railway Station. This early 20th-century train station is home to the Western Maryland Scenic Railroad
column2: known regionally as "Mountain Thunder". The Western Maryland Scenic Railroad offers three hour round trip tours from Cumberland to Frostburg using restored 1916 Baldwin Steam Locomotive Number 734 or "Mountain Thunder" (Currently out of service). The Western Maryland Railway Station is part of the Canal Place Heritage Area
column3: the first in the state of Maryland.

column4: and bicyclists. There are campsites approximately every five miles along the trail.

column1: The C&O Canal has its Western Terminus at Canal Place
column2: and it is possible to travel by foot or bicycle from here to Washington
column3: D.C. along the canal towpath - a distance of roughly 185 miles (298 km). The Great Allegheny Passage is a 148-mile (238 km) hiking/biking trail starting in Pittsburgh
column4: PA and ending in Cumberland
column5: MD where it connects with the C&O Canal towpath and continues to historic Georgetown in Washington D.C.

column1: The Narrows is a compact notched valley that Wills Creek has carved into Wills Mountain.  Inventor Frederick John Bahr bought Wills Mountain and built his log cabin on top.
The National Road (U.S. Route 40) and a number of railroad lines pass through this steep
column3: and rocky river valley on the edge of Cumberland. On the northeast side of Wills Mountain
column4: sits a rocky outcropping known as Lover's Leap. The name comes from a Native American Romeo and Juliet legend. The tale tells how a jilted lover met his end by jumping off this ledge. Today
column5: the rocks high above the water provide extensive views of the Allegheny Mountains. Lover's Leap has been frequently romanticized by postcard pictures of this valley
column6: including those taken by George Steward in 1950 and published in the 1953 book U.S. 40.

column1: The Paw Paw Tunnel is one of the world's longest canal tunnels and was one of the greatest engineering feats of its day.
The Sideling Hill road cut is a 340-foot (100 m) deep road cut where Interstate 68 cuts through Sideling Hill. It is notable as an impressive man-made mountain pass
column2: visible from miles away and one of the best rock exposures in Maryland and indeed in the entire northeastern United States. Almost 810 feet (250 m) of strata in a tightly folded syncline are exposed in this road cut.

column1: Some of Cumberland's most architecturally significant homes are located in the Washington Street Historic District. Considered the elite residential area when the city was at its economic peak
column2: Washington Street was home to the region's leading citizens including the president of the C&O Canal. Significant public buildings include the Allegany County Courthouse
column3: Allegany County Library
column4: and Emmanuel Episcopal Church
column5: located on the site of Fort Cumberland. It features Gothic Revival architecture with three large Tiffany windows
column7: and ammunition magazine cellars.The 1850 Emmanuel Episcopal Church
column8: standing at the eastern end of the Washington Street Historic District
column9: is one of Maryland's most outstanding examples of early Gothic Revival architecture. The Allegany County Courthouse dominates the city's skyline. It was designed in 1893 by local architect Wright Butler. The Queen City Hotel was built by the B&O during the 1870s. The battle to preserve it was lost when the building was demolished in 1972. Temple B'er Chayim's 1865 Gothic Revival building is one of the oldest surviving synagogue buildings in the United States.

column1: Cumberland's has Council–manager government composed of an elected mayor
column3: and an appointed city administrator. Cumberland's current mayor is Ray Morriss
column4: who was elected in 2018 after defeating two-term incumbent Brian Grim. The current city council members are Eugene Frazier
column7: and Richard "Rock" Cioni. The city council holds public meetings twice per month.Cumberland is in Maryland's 6th congressional district and is represented in the United States Congress by Representative David Trone and Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen.

column1: In 1864 the state legislature provided funds
column2: and a structure for obtaining local funds from taxes and private donations for the purpose of funding schools for Negroes. The first public school for African-Americans in Cumberland operated in a colored YMCA on Independence Street
column3: and was named the Mary Hoye school. In 1923 a new school for blacks was built on Frederick Street. In 1941 an election was held of students and faculty
column4: and the school was renamed George Washington Carver School. In addition to serving the local population
column5: many black people from surrounding areas in West Virginia sent their children to Carver because of the inadequate local facilities. The schools were integrated in 1955
column6: when 54 negro children attended the white schools. In 1956
column7: 3 black students became the first to graduated from Allegany County's newly integrated schools.The offices of Allegany County Public Schools are located in Cumberland. The city is served by Allegany High School and Fort Hill High School

column1: Water and sewer service is supplied by the City of Cumberland. The municipal watershed is located to the north within the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Water is drawn from two lakes on city land

column4: while natural gas service is supplied by Columbia Gas of Maryland. There was once a working oil well that pumped crude oil from a location near the Fruit Bowl in the Cumberland Narrows. Hospitals include UPMC Western Maryland and Thomas B. Finan Center.

column1: The primary public transportation in the City of Cumberland is bus service provided by Allegany County Transit. This service consists of five scheduled routes that reach most areas of the City and provide access to most public facilities. Amtrak

column4: which runs between Washington
column7: Illinois. The Cumberland Amtrak Station is located downtown at Queen City Drive and East Harrison Street.
